newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bond prices rise after European rate cuts.
newsitem.headline: Danish bond prices rise after European rate cuts.

text.p: A wave of European rate cuts sent the Danish benchmark bond price 0.45 point higher on Thursday afternoon and left dealers wondering if Denmark would follow suit soon.
The Bundesbank's high-than-expected 0.30 point repo cut left dealers wondering if there was scope for further trimming and if Denmark would follow suit.

"That the market was allowed to rise could be taken as an acknowledgement that there could be further German cuts," a dealer said, adding that he had expected Denmark to follow Germany with a 0.10-0.20 point cut of its own.
The benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 closed at 105.08 point, compared to Wednesday's 104.63 close, after touching 105.12.
Its September future ended 0.06 up, at 104.80, with 102 contracts traded.
The yield gap to Germany narrowed two basis points from its morning level, to 94 bp.
The crown strengthened to 3.8632 per mark from an opening 3.8655, seen as increasing the likelihood of an imminent Danish rate cut. --Steve Weizman, Copenhagen newsroom, 45-33-969650
